table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the sound, and not to any letter or glyph.

table.name: mem
table.column:
Some possible objects of this verb are {pab:n}, {chut:n}, {nab:n}, {'Ip:n}, {lurDech:n}, {quv:n}, and {tIgh:n}.
In the context of a vow or promise which has been made (see {'Ip:v} and {lay':v}), {pab:v:nolink} means "to keep" or "to fulfill".[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This describes an obviously deliberate slight bending of grammatical rules, a common way to construct {mu'mey ru':n}.
The square brackets in the definition are as they appear on {KGT p.176:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: See {jej:v} and {jejHa':v} for two idiomatic expressions involving {pach:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This was defined as "nothing, none" in {TKD:src} and as "no one" in {KGT:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is used to describe something that was expected to occur, or could conceivably occur, but has not.
▶ {pawpu' 'avwI' paghDIch:sen:nolink} "the zeroth guard has arrived" (no guard has arrived even though one or more are expected)

table.name: mem
table.column: This is an emphatic alternative for {not:adv}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
In Klingon, the conjunction {pagh:conj} cannot be used to present two options to someone, such as "surrender or die". {bIjegh pagh bIHegh:sen:nolink} means "you're surrendering or you're dying" (as if the speaker is not sure which is happening). Instead, the sentence must be recast as "If you don't surrender, you will die". See {bIjeghbe'chugh vaj bIHegh!:sen} for further information.
When connecting multiple sentences, only the final conjunction is needed. See the example under {qoj:conj}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Hermit crabs belong to the superfamily Paguroidea.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is defined in {TKD:src} as "gown". In {TNK:src}, it is used for "dress", while {paH bID:n} is used for "skirt".

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {pan qeylIS betleH 'ej jach molor 'etlh HoS:sen:nolink} "Kahless's bat'leth sparks, And Molor's mighty sword roars."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This means to determine the solution to a {ngajrun:n}, {poymar:n}, {Qay'mol:n}, or so on. A slang way to say this is {SIHHa'moH:v}.
A solution may come from a "spark" ({pan:v:1}) of insight.

table.name: mem
table.column: The Klingon Dictionary was published by Pocket Books. See also {buq:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The son of Torghn ({torghen:n:name}), and the main character of the holodeck simulation in {KCD:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: contents, table of contents (of a book)

This is used for "Contents" (the heading for the table of contents) in the 2nd edition of the {paq'batlh:src}. In comparison, the heading of the "Contents" printed on the {Klingon Monopoly:src} box was {ngaS 'aplo':sen}.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is the name of a book recounting the legendary life and deeds of {qeylIS'e' lIjlaHbe'bogh vay':n:name}. Note that the name of the book is in {no' Hol:n}, and that in modern standard Klingon "Book of Honor" would be {batlh paq:n:nolink}; the apostrophe represents what may be a missing grammatical element that would explain the transposition.[1]
The {paq'batlh:n:nolink} is divided into three major parts, titled respectively {paq'yav:n} "Ground Book", {paq'raD:n} "Force Book", and {paq'QIH:n} "Impact Book".
See also {tIq'ghob:n:hyp} for a hypothetical similar grammatical construction.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word can (but doesn't have to) take an object indicating what is being meditated about or reflected upon. It does not connote "entreat", so "pray" may not be an appropriate translation.

table.name: mem
table.column: a mid-sized bird with particularly garish coloring (at least from a Klingon point of view)
In golf, "one under par" ({bIng:n} means "under") is known as a "birdie", and golfers have traditionally worn garishly coloured clothing.
a mid-sized bird with particularly garish colouring

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a mineral consisting of hydrated calcium sulphate, having a number of applications including as a precursor of plaster.

table.name: mem
table.column: [1] {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2017:src}, [2] {DSC - Si Vis Pacem, Para Bellum:src}

table.name: mem
table.column: This concept has much more aggressive and intense connotations than the translation implies.[1; 2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is rarely used in direct address. Instead, couples call each other by {bang pong:n}.[1, p.199]

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a romantic or courtship date.

table.name: mem
table.column: See {pel'aQDaj ghorpa':sen:idiom} for an idiomatic expression related to lateness, and {'eb:n} for how to express the concept of a missed opportunity.

▶ {jIpaSqu'mo' narghpu' qaSuchmeH 'eb.:sen:nolink} "Because I'm very late, the opportunity to visit you has escaped."[2] ▶ {qaSuch vIneH 'ach narghpu' 'eb. jIpaSqu'.:sen:nolink} "I want to visit you, but the opportunity has escaped. I am very late."[2] ▶ {qaSuchlaHbe'. jIpaSqu' vaj narghpu' 'eb.:sen:nolink} "I cannot visit you. I am very late, thus the opportunity has escaped."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: A {paSjav:n:nolink} is a Klingon tree whose bark is cut into strips and eaten along with certain foods or else is ground up (like {ngat:n:2}) and added to some other kinds of foods. (It's occasionally just ripped off of the tree and eaten then and there.) Non-Klingons who eat too much {paSjav:n:nolink} tend to start coughing. Klingons think this is pretty funny and never seem to tire of it. {tera' paSjav:n@@tera':n, paSjav:n} is a way to refer to cinnamon.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: The usual way to say "a pair of socks" is {paSlogh chang'eng:n@@paSlogh:n, chang'eng:n}; {tu'mI' chang'eng:n@@tu'mI':n, chang'eng:n} is odd, but would be understood.[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: In usage, this might be preceded by something like {ghIH wep:sen@@ghIH:v:1, wep:n:1} (or {Soy' wep:sen@@Soy':v:2, wep:n:1}) "the shirt is sloppy/disheveled".[1]
The example mixes the Rukevet and Vospeg dialects, but this isn't noted and is probably just a mistake.

table.name: mem
table.column: fabric used in carpets and rugs
This is not used for fabric used for clothing, for which see {weSjech:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This refers to systems in the physical (or physical-like) sense, as opposed to a methodology, which is {Ho'DoS:n}.[2]
Note that the Klingon term for a star system is {Hovtay':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is what Klingons would call the Terran vegetable.

table.name: mem
table.column: Emerald is a variety of the mineral beryl. Beryl Patmore is a character on the TV show Downton Abbey.

table.name: mem
table.column: See under {yaS:n} for the ranks of officers.

▶ {Hung buv rav:n}[3] ▶ {qaSDI' nenghep, qa' patlh chu' chav tlhIngan SuvwI'.:sen:nolink} "The Age of Ascension marks a new level of spiritual attainment by a Klingon warrior."[4] ▶ {SIQwI' lu'oy'moHmeH juppu'Daj 'oy'naQmey lo' chaH. SuvwI' qa' patlh veb chavlaHmeH tlhIngan lo'chu' chaH. toDujDaj toblu'.:sen:nolink} "The Painstik is employed by friends of the recipent who use the devices to inflict pain in a manner which will allow the Klingon to attain a higher state of spirituality as a warrior, proving his mettle."[5]

table.name: mem
table.column: be ranked, have a status, be graded; be sorted

To sort a list of English words alphabetically, use a construction such as {wa'DIch a, HochDIch z:sen:nolink} (or {wa'DIch z, HochDIch a:sen:nolink} for reverse order). For Klingon words, use {wa'DIch bay, HochDIch qaghwI':sen:nolink} or {wa'DIch qaghwI', HochDIch bay:sen:nolink}. To reverse a list, use {DopmoH:v}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column:
When the object is singular, this means "rank" in the sense of "grade".[2]
When used with the "compare" meaning, the object of the verb must be plural. The implication is that the things are ranked in comparison to one another.[1] When used to mean "sort", the object is not a list (as a whole) but the things in the list, the things to be ranked or sorted.[3]
The example sentence was suggested to Okrand in Klingon, who provided the English translation.
▶ {wo'rIv patlhmoH HoD.:sen:nolink} "The captain ranked Worf." (This means the captain made a judgment about Worf relative to someone else or a group.)
[1] {KLI mailing list 2018.02.06:src}, [2] {KLI mailing list 2018.02.07:src}, [3] {KLI mailing list 2018.02.10:src}

table.name: mem
table.column:
{paw:v:nolink} works in a similar way to {jaH:v}.[2]
Do not confuse this with {paw':v:1}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
The verb {paw':v:nolink} always takes a plural subject, namely, the things in motion which collide. When the subject is people, the verb is usually interpreted with the slang meaning of "butting heads" (see {paw':v:2,slang}). To describe the collision of something moving with something stationary, use {ngeQ:v} instead.[2; 3]
Do not confuse this with {paw:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: As with the literal usage of this verb (see {paw':v:1}), when used in its slang meaning, it also takes a plural subject, in this case the people who butt heads. To say that two people collide without implying that they are butting heads, {ngeQ:v} might be used with {-chuq:v:suff}.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This was shortened over time from {pawmeH 'aD:n@@paw:v, -meH:v, 'aD:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Another way of saying "You'll regret this!" is "You'll pay for this!"

table.name: mem
table.column: The name of the consonant "p" in Klingon is {pay:sen:nolink}, and "an" is an article in English, so "p-article".

table.name: mem
table.column:
This word is homophonous with {pa':n:2}. However, {pa'Daq:n:nolink} unambiguously means "in the room".
The {bIS'ub:n} of a {pa':n:1h,nolink} is its {rav:n:1}, and its {'aqroS:n:1} is its {rav'eq:n}. If the {pa':n:1h,nolink} is in the top story of a {qach:n}, then its {rav'eq:n} is called its {pa' beb:n}. The walls of a {pa':n:1h,nolink} are {tlhoy':n}; if the other side of a wall is {Hur:n}, then the wall is also called a {pa' reD:n}. The word {tlhoy':n} can refer to any side of a room; a ceiling/floor between stories is called a {tlhoy' SaS:n}.
This word is defined as "room" in {TKD:src}, as "enclosed area" in {KGT:src}, and as "chamber" in {BoP:src} (see {cha'puj pa':n}).

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is homophonous with {pa':n:1}. As a locative, {pa':n:2,nolink} never takes the suffix {-Daq:n:suff}, and can only mean "there" ({TKD 3.3.5:src}). In contrast, {pa'Daq:n:nolink} can only mean "in the room".

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the ceiling ({'aqroS:n:1}) of a room which is on the top (or only) story of a structure. If there are rooms above it, then it is a {rav'eq:n}.[1]
ceiling of a top storey room

table.name: mem
table.column: In comparison, {'op ret:n} means "at some point in the past".[1]
In German, the word for "in the past" is "damals", which can be pulled apart as "da" ("there", {pa':n:2}) and "mal(s)" ("times", {-logh:n:num,suff}).

table.name: mem
table.column: [1] {DSC - Si Vis Pacem, Para Bellum:src}, [2] {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2019:src}

table.name: mem
table.column: [1] {DSC - Si Vis Pacem, Para Bellum:src}, [2] {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2019:src}

table.name: mem
table.column:
{tlhIH:n}:{pagh:n:1h} = {pe-:v:pref,nolink} (imp.)
Generally, when a verb describing a state of being is used as an imperative, the suffixes {-'egh:v} and {-moH:v} are used with it.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is soaked in {chanDoq:n} and eaten.

table.name: mem
table.column:
There is no known noun or verb for blizzard, but one can say {peDqu':sen@@peD:v, -qu':v}, {pe'vIl peD:sen@@pe'vIl:adv, peD:v}, or even {pe'vIl peDqu':sen@@pe'vIl:adv, peD:v, -qu':v}.[2]
This verb can also be used for other things whose falling motion resembles snowfall, for example breadcrumbs, confetti, or ashes. The falling thing is the subject.[3]
The example line appeared in the Kate Bush album "50 Words for Snow".
▶ {peDtaH 'ej chIS qo':sen@@peD:v, -taH:v, 'ej:conj, chIS:v, qo':n} "It's snowing and the world is white."[4]

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb can also be used without an object. See {pegh:v:2}.
In {TKD:src}, this is defined in the K-E side as "keep something secret", and in the E-K side as "secret, keep something secret".

table.name: mem
table.column:
See {rav:n:2} for an example of how to talk about classified information.
This verb can also be used with an object. See {pegh:v:1}.
▶ {pegh De'vetlh.@@pegh:v:2, De':n, -vetlh:n} "That is classified information."[1] ▶ {De' pegh vIghaj.@@De':n, pegh:v:2, vI-:v, ghaj:v} "I have secret information."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column:
These are a set of proverbs which are most frequently used in situations where the speaker wishes to show that he or she can keep a secret under any condition.[2]
This is also infrequently shortened to {pegh vIttlhegh:n:nolink}.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiomatic expression {pel'aQDaj ghorpa':sen:idiom} "before it breaks its shell", meaning "before it's too late" or "while there's still time".

table.name: mem
table.column: This literally means "before it breaks its shell", and as an idiomatic expression it has the meaning of "before it's too late" or "while there's still time".
▶ {pel'aQDaj ghorpa' qama' yIHoH.:sen:nolink} "Kill the prisoner now, while you've got a chance."

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the part of the day when it is light out (as opposed to {ram:n}).[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: A planet in the Cardassian Union.

table.name: mem
table.column: Known types of Klingon torpedoes include the {pach peng:n}, {moratlh ro':n}, and {notqa' pach:n}.
"Ping" is the sonar sound made by submarines.

table.name: mem
table.column: A "pep" rally raises a team's spirits.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a movement of air or water.
A "currant" is a type of raisin ({pep:v}-{en:sen:nolink}).

table.name: mem
table.column: This word connotes intention, targeting specific victims.[1]
The example sentence is a lip-match for {'ej DochmeywIj vItlhapqa'meH}.
▶ {'ej Dojmey wID, vInDa'ma' peq.:sen@@'ej:conj, Dojmey:n, wID:v, vInDa':n, -ma':n, peq:v} "He has killed many of our people."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {bISuvtaHvIS qarDaS bIghHa' peQ botjan Daveghchu'.:sen:nolink} "Fight your way beyond magnetic shield of Cardassian prison."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is written as {peQ chem:n:nolink} (with a space) in {TKDA:src}. The space has been removed for consistency with the other terms ending in {chem:n:hyp}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The verb {per:v:nolink} usually means "to assign or attach a name to", but it can also be used for such notions as "ascertain, specify, pin down". One way to ask for the time is {rep yIper!:sen}, literally, "Label the hour!"[2]
This was defined as just "label" in {TKD:src}. The additional meanings come from a newsgroup post.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: A code name usually ends in {Qu':n}, e.g., {targh Qu':n:nolink} "Operation Targ".[1, p.48]

table.name: mem
table.column: This applies to trees, etc., not to body parts.

table.name: mem
table.column: The object of this verb is the thing which is given out.
"PEZ" is a brand of candy dispenser.

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: This is a device or substance used by the {HaqwI':n} to bond broken bones in place.

This seems to refer to a device similar to one used by the Federation called a bone-knitting laser (knitter for short), bone regenerator, or osteo-regenerator.
"Duck tape". Possibly related to {pet:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Take action! Do it! Make it so!

This is used when addressing multiple people. To address a single person, say {yIvang!:sen@@yI-:v, vang:v}
Watch Gowron say this: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/QAd6OugYyxw}

table.name: mem
table.column: This is almost how "pH" is pronounced in French.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a tool knife, as opposed to a weapon knife.

table.name: mem
table.column: This might be said to strike ({mup:v}) something.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: to do something at once, as a single event
This idiomatic expression literally means "to forcefully sweep away".
▶ {romuluSnganpu' Dujmey DIQaw'pu'; pe'vIl DIbI'chu'pu'.} "We destroyed the Romulans' ships all at once."

table.name: mem
table.column:
This idiomatic expression conveys the idea that someone is particularly agile or nimble or spry.
The verb {roS:v:2} means "to use the third toe". It is also homophonous with a verb {roS:v:1} meaning "to lick". However, it's possible that this verb is actually an otherwise unknown or archaic verb {roS:v:3,hyp} meaning "to be agile".
be agile, be nimble, be spry

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a Klingon greeting used for welcoming a group to an event.
This expression seems to be based on the near-homophony of {paw:v} and {paw':v:2}. Thus, it only makes sense when applied to more than one person.

table.name: mem
table.column: The word {mIvwa'mey:n@@mIvwa':n, -mey:n} is used to keep a tally or score. To say "out of", use a construction like {loSlogh pe''egh; vaghlogh nID:sen@@loS:n:1,num, -logh:n:num, pe''egh:v, vagh:n:1,num, -logh:n, nID:v} (i.e., 4 out of 5 points). This is used even if the person stopped after four and didn't attempt to get the fifth point.[2]
Another meaning of "to score" is to cut a notch in something.

table.name: mem
table.column: Note that {ghaj:v} is used with this noun to indicate fault or blame.

table.name: mem
table.column: Vinegar is a common condiment for "fish and chips" ({vIS:sen:nolink} and {chIp:sen:nolink} backwards).

table.name: mem
table.column:
It's unclear whether this means the subject has a cautious distrust of someone or something (as in "the Klingon was suspicious of others"), or if the subject is causing a sense of cautious distrust (as in "a suspicious package"). That's likely a deliberate joke (i.e., the definition of this word is itself suspicious).
The homophony with {pIH:v:1} might indicate that they are the same word, and that the subject is suspicious in the sense of expecting something unspecified. The word {nub:v:nolink} also seems to cover the "causing suspicion" meaning.

table.name: mem
table.column: Another way to express this, if being emphatic, is periphrastically: {V 'ej V-qa' ('ej V-qa'...):sen:nolink}.
▶ {qagh vISoppu' 'ej vISopqa'pu' 'ej vISopqa'pu':sen@@qagh:n, vI-:v, Sop:v, -pu':v, 'ej:conj, vI-:v, Sop:v, -qa':v, -pu':v, 'ej:conj, vI-:v, Sop:v, -qa':v, -pu':v} "I've eaten gagh many times"

table.name: mem
table.column: Don't trust those who frequently smile.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the basic tenet of Vulcan philosophy, and the idea translates awkwardly into Klingon. The translation means something like "different things continue to be together always".

▶ {qum DuSaQmeyDaq 'Irghbe'meH ghotpu' nabmey ghojmoH, 'ej pIj tay'taH Doch pIm num.:sen:nolink} "In public schools, it teaches procedures so that people don't bully, and it promotes Infinite Diversity in Infinite Combinations."
[1] {Air & Space Magazine, August 2016:src}, [2] {Pop Culture Hero Coalition announcement:src} ({KLI mailing list 2016.11.30:src})

table.name: mem
table.column: be stimulated, be inspired, be motivated
This refers to motivation by an external source, in contrast to {vaw:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is not defined as such, but to translate "apathy" or "apathy creature" for the Klingon Christmas Carol, one of MO's suggestions was {pIlHa'wI':n:nolink} "unmotivated one".[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This can be applied to music.[1, p.71]

table.name: mem
table.column: The book "Two Years Before the Mast" chronicled the 1834 voyage of the sailing brig named the Pilgrim.

table.name: mem
table.column: In this slang sense, {pIn:n:nolink} is never used alone, but is always the second noun in a noun-noun construction. The non-slang term for "expert" is {po'wI':n}.[1, p.158]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a reference to the Pink Floyd album "The Wall", the songs of which were played at a concert in Berlin eight months after the fall of the Berlin Wall.

table.name: mem
table.column: This slang term may be used in informal settings, but never in a science lab or heavy-duty workshop.

table.name: mem
table.column: Glory to you and your House.
This is a ritualized phrase said during {muvtay:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Its claws are used as food and require breaking.

table.name: mem
table.column: pIpyuS pach DaSop DaneHchugh pIpyuS puS DaghornIS.
If you want to eat pipius claw, you'll have to break a few pipiuses.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is an expression telling someone (often a child) to get started on something or to devote more effort to a project.

table.name: mem
table.column:
A specialised word is used to indicate a time in the future for the following units: ▶ {jaj:n} "day" - {leS:n} "days from now" ▶ {jar:n} "month" - {waQ:n} "months from now" ▶ {DIS:n:2} "year" - {nem:n} "years from now"
For other units of time, {pIq:n:nolink} is used.
▶ {cha' tup pIq:n@@cha':n, tup:n, pIq:n} "two minutes from now"

table.name: mem
table.column: Little is known about how {pIqaD:n:nolink} works, except that it is not an alphabet.[2]

If interpreted as a sentence, {pIqaD:sen@@pI-:v, qaD:v} literally means "we challenge you".
Prior to {DSC:src}, the {pIqaD:n:nolink} seen in the shows, movies, and videogames were arranged based on aesthetics and had no relation to the language. Some of the same sequences of symbols were even used to mean different things in different contexts. In {DSC:src}, both within the show itself and in promotional posters and videos released prior to its debut, Klingon is written in {pIqaD:n:nolink} treating the symbols as an alphabet. The mapping between the twenty-six symbols and Okrand's Latin transcription has a one-to-one grapheme-phoneme correspondence (e.g., so that {tlh:sen:nolink} is written as one symbol), and originated from an unknown source at Paramount and was popularised by the Klingon Language Institute. There is no official explanation for why {pIqaD:n:nolink} is an alphabet in {DSC:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This can refer to either a person or an animal and takes whichever plural suffix is appropriate.
The question of whether an animal can be an athlete came up during the Q & A session.

table.name: mem
table.column: be indirect, be roundabout, be devious

table.name: mem
table.column: This can be applied to land, animals, and people, as well as many other things.
The request was for a word which could be applied "land, animals, people", and it was confirmed during the Q & A session that this word is quite broad in scope.

table.name: mem
table.column: The moon ({maS:n}) of the Klingon Homeworld ({Qo'noS:n}), and the site of a major energy facility ({HoS waw':n}).
It is misspelled {pIraQSIS:n:nolink} in the first edition of {paq'batlh p.118-119:src}. This is corrected in the second edition.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the underside of an object, and not to its interior bottom (which is its {bIS'ub:n}).
This is a reference to Pyramus, a character played by Nick Bottom in the play-within-a-play in Shakespeare's "A Midsummer Night's Dream".

table.name: mem
table.column: done (uttered at the completion of a task)

This is similar to saying "It's done!", "I've done it!", "It's finished!", "All done!", and so on.
Watch Gowron say this: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/4gCJJiBXaE4}

table.name: mem
table.column: This actually appears in the plural on the {BoP:src} poster: {pIvchem lIngwI' DaHmey:n:nolink}.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a special, rather pungent Klingon beverage.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is used regardless of the material the incense is made of.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This verb does not carry a connotation of bulk due to body fat or the like, for which see {ror:v}.[2]
It can also be used in typography to describe a "bold" font. See {ngutlh tu'qom:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: animal that makes noise at dawn
This is the literary name for a {'uSgheb:n} or a {jajlo' Qa':n}. It is commonly used in operas and plays, but rarely in everyday speech.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This refers to hair from the neck down. For example, "arm hair" is {DeS pob:n@@DeS:n:1, pob:n}. It is also used to talk about ear hair or nose hair. Using this word to refer to facial hair (see {rol:n} and {loch:n}) or head hair (see {jIb:n}) is possible, but would be considered very strange to do.[2]
This word can also be used for animals to refer to their body hair or fur.[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is missing from the K-E side of {TKD:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: See {mIvDaq pogh cha':sen} for an idiom involving {pogh:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: To indicate "period of time ago" or "period of time from now", {ret:n} and {pIq:n} are used in place of {poH:n}, respectively.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is a rare and dangerous resource which is found on the sacred planet of {bo'retlh:n}. Touching one induces visions of the future, and removing one requires a great sacrifice. It can be used as a power source in time-travel technology.
To Klingons outside of {bo'retlh:n}, time crystals were a myth, a symbol of Kahless, and the namesake of {Qo'noS:n}.
In Greek philosophy, "Chronos" is the personification of time. If time crystals are the namesake of {Qo'noS:n:nolink}, then the similarity to the planet's name is not a coincidence.

table.name: mem
table.column: the matter is unimportant, it does not make a difference
This idiomatic expression literally means someone "can either keep it or discard it".

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a long, heavy pole with something sort of rounded at one end used for bashing a door and the like.[1]
This appears to be made up of {pom:n} and {tut:n:1}. The {tut:n:1h,nolink} part makes sense, but it's unclear what {pom:n:nolink} is doing here.

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: To express the concept of doing something in someone's name, consider using {DoQ:v} with {woQ:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The sentence in {paq'batlh:src} had a typo in the 1st edition: it said {pongwI''e':sen:nolink} rather than {pongwIj'e':sen:nolink}. This is corrected in the 2nd edition.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {roD 'oHvaD juHqo' ponglu' neH.:sen:nolink} "[Qo'noS] is usually referred to as simply 'The Homeworld'."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: Any formal recognition of an accomplishment or accomplishments.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the chemical element with the symbol Na and atomic number 11.

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb is also used to describe the act of issuing a challenge to a duel (see {Hay':v}).

table.name: mem
table.column: This word can also refer to the "heart" suit in a deck of playing cards (see {Degh:n:1}).[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is probably shortened from {por tlhIch pur:sen@@por:n, tlhIch:n, pur:v}.
Maltz didn't know what kind of leaf this might be referring to.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the best temperature to serve blood wine.
This appears in the body of {KGT:src} but not in the word lists.

table.name: mem
table.column: Maltz had a hard time thinking of an everyday sentence containing this phrase.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: Klingons don't talk all that much about bodily functions as a group, but they certainly do talk about specific bodily functions (see {porgh mIw:n}).

table.name: mem
table.column: This word does not appear in canon, but is an obvious construction based on {porghQeD:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: When referring to one's left and right sides, possessive suffixes are used.[2] See also {lurgh:n} for other words related to spatial directions.

table.name: mem
table.column: If winning is not important, then why keep score?

table.name: mem
table.column: It is only a coincidence that this word is homophonous with {povjaj!:excl}
This refers to a line in "Lady Madonna" by The Beatles: "Tuesday afternoon is never-ending."

table.name: mem
table.column: This expression is used to express a wish that something turn out well. It is only a coincidence that it is homophonous with the name of the weekday {povjaj:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a real mystery, something that confounds people.
Hercule Poirot and Miss Marple are the names of two detectives in Agatha Christie's mystery novels.

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: corner of the street, corner of a piece of paper
"The House at Pooh Corner" is a volume of stories about Winnie the Pooh.

table.name: mem
table.column: While this does not have the impact of {romuluS HIq:n}, it is still impressive.

table.name: mem
table.column: The slang expression {qIvon belmoH:sen} is also used sometimes for going to the toilet.
A "pooch" is a slang word for "dog", an animal which drinks out of toilets.

table.name: mem
table.column: The word lists say "washroom". The "bathroom" definition comes from the example sentence on p.170.

table.name: mem
table.column: In the episode {TOS - Plato's Stepchildren:src}, Spock is forced to sing a song, "Maiden Wine", whose lyrics contain the phrase "bitter dregs".

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb is also used for scalene triangles.[2]
It is unclear what this means when applied to polygons and polyhedra.

table.name: mem
table.column: The line which used this noun was revised in {paq'batlh 2ed:src} to use the verb {puj:v:nolink} instead.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is missing from the E-K side of {TKD:src}.

▶ {jaghpu'ra' bopujmoHtaHvIS, ghur tuqmeyraj quv.:sen@@jagh:n, -pu':n, -ra':n, bo-:v, pujmoH:v, -taH:v, -vIS:v, ghur:v, tuq:n, -mey:n, -raj:n, quv:n} "Honor will rise in your houses as you bring your enemies to their knees."[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is missing from the E-K side of {TKD:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: There is no honor in attacking the weak.
There is no honour in attacking the weak.

table.name: mem
table.column: This might refer to a deep voice, or a low note in music.
A pun often results in a low groan.

table.name: mem
table.column: For a symbolic fall (i.e., loss of status), see {lu:v}.
The definition in {TKD:src} just says "fall". In {s.k 1999.11.05:src} this is glossed as "fall down or fall off of something".

table.name: mem
table.column: by that time, by the time that (something) occurred

This idiomatic expression literally means "when it falls". It is most frequently heard without a subject, but when a subject is specified, the most common is {'etlh:n}. Another word may be chosen as the subject as a form of word play, as long as it is something that can fall (e.g., {DaS:n}, {'obmaQ:n}, {nagh:n}, {rutlh:n}). When used idiomatically, {pumDI':sen:nolink} always precedes the main clause.[1]
▶ {tagha' pawpu' meb 'ach pumDI' Heghpu' qagh.:sen:nolink} "The guest finally arrived, but by then the gagh had died."[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: Note that the conjunction {ghap:conj} normally follows the nouns it's joining.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {jabbI'ID pup:sen:nolink}: {Qapchu'meH 'aqroS chuq:sen:nolink}: {cha' vI' chorgh loghqammey:sen:nolink} "High Resolution - Maximum Effective Range - 3.5 Light Years"

table.name: mem
table.column: Klingons pride themselves on being exact. If it's necessary to hedge one's bets adverbially, {chaq:adv} and {ghaytan:adv} are acceptable.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is used only when speaking to young children or pets.

table.name: mem
table.column: To say "to smoke" (as in inhale nicotine from burning {toba'qo:n}), use {tlhIch pur:sen@@tlhIch:n, pur:v}.[2] One can also say {por pur:sen} for inhaling smoke from other kinds of plants.
"Purr". Also, the words for inhale and exhale together sound like "poor wretch" ({pur rech:sen:nolink}).

table.name: mem
table.column: be few, be several, be a handful
The word {puS:v:nolink} is used in comparative constructions. See {... X law' ... X puS:sen}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Based on the examples, this verb can be used for both atmospheric and space flight.

▶ {Hoch tlhIngan DujDaq So'wI' jomlu'. puvtaHbogh Duj ngabmoHlaw' So'wI'.:sen:nolink} "All Klingon vessels are equipped with a cloaking device, allowing the ship to fly in a state of practical invisibility."[2] ▶ {puvbogh targh yIjal@@puv:v, -bogh:v, targh:n, yI-:v, jal:v} "Think about a flying targ."[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: {puyjaq'a':n@@puyjaq:n, -'a':n} has been used by some people for "supernova".

table.name: mem
table.column:
This word is descended from the archaic word for "spike" ({pu':n:2}).
The Klingon equivalent to a phaser is a {nISwI':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
In modern Klingon, the spike on the toe of a boot is always called a {DaSpu':n}, never just {pu':n:2,nolink} alone.[1]
This word takes the plural suffix {-mey:n}, unlike when {pu':n:3} refers to a horn (animal body part).[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the horn of an animal. When it's necessary to distinguish this from a spike (such as on a boot, see {pu':n:2}), one can say {Ha'DIbaH pu':n@@Ha'DIbaH:n:1, pu':n:3} or {DI'raq loD pu':n@@DI'raq:n, loD:n, pu':n:3} and so on. It takes the plural suffix {-Du':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is misspelled {pu'bej:n:nolink} on {KGT p.56:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: map, plan (as in a building plan), blueprint
This word refers to the plan of a physical object, and not to a procedure or the plan for an event (which would be {nab:n}).

Augustus W. N. Pugin was an English architect who assisted in the design of the Palace of Westminster.
The 2009 {Star Trek:src} movie has a deleted scene with the line: {buqmeylIjDaq DIvI' De' pu'jInmey... 'ach pu'jInmeylIj bIHbe'.:sen:nolink}

table.name: mem
table.column: A folk etymology says that the word "ginger" comes from the Sanskrit for "horn-body" ({pu':n:3}, {porgh:n}).

table.name: mem
table.column: This is really just the plural of {pu'veng:n}, which is why it is formed with {-mey:n} and not {-Du':n}.[1]
